text:
taken from the betfair developer page:
FILL OR KILL BETS
...
*Please note:* the matching algorithm for Fill or Kill orders behaves slightly differently to that for standard limit orders. Whereas the price on a limit order represents the lowest price at which any fragment should be matched, the price on a Fill or Kill order represents the lower limit of the Volume Weighted Average Price (“VWAP”) for the entire volume matched. So, for instance, a Fill or Kill order with price = 5.4 and size = 10 might be matched as £2 @ 5.5, £6 @ 5.4 and £2 @ 5.3.

I kinda dont want any bets below my specified price, even if it still works on the average. My EV still goes down there? :confused:

elements.text:

I kinda dont want any bets below my specified price, even if it still works on the average. My EV still goes down there?

text: What's so bad about the FoK implementation?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: What's so bad about the FoK implementation?

text: Fill or kill works perfectly for my requirements. I determine the minimum average price I want, and I will take as much volume as requested to average that price. I have already decided that the price is OK, so why would I want to get less volume at a slightly higher price?

elements.text: Fill or kill works perfectly for my requirements. I determine the minimum average price I want, and I will take as much volume as requested to average that price. I have already decided that the price is OK, so why would I want to get less volume at a slightly higher price?

text: I also work on the "target" average price by calculating the average price offered for a set payout/liability. This may span two or more offered prices

elements.text: I also work on the "target" average price by calculating the average price offered for a set payout/liability. This may span two or more offered prices

text: The alternative is crafting something that leaves offers there, and cancels the remaining, which in terms of execution, is inferior to a single atomic transaction

elements.text: The alternative is crafting something that leaves offers there, and cancels the remaining, which in terms of execution, is inferior to a single atomic transaction

text: The only problem you may have is in very low liquidity markets, where you are asking for more volume than is really on offer (excluding the default "catch-all" offers that are often left there to match "mistakes"). But I would never bet into these markets as it just isn't worth the effort (and this comes from someone who bets on ITF matches)

elements.text: The only problem you may have is in very low liquidity markets, where you are asking for more volume than is really on offer (excluding the default "catch-all" offers that are often left there to match "mistakes"). But I would never bet into these markets as it just isn't worth the effort (and this comes from someone who bets on ITF matches)
